Literature Review: Historical criminology has emerged as a vibrant field of study, bridging the gap between criminology and history to explore the temporal dimensions of crime and justice. This literature review delves into the scope, significance, and future directions of historical criminology, drawing on recent scholarly discussions and research findings. The exploration begins with an examination of the various conceptions of historical criminology, followed by an assessment of its significance to the broader field of criminology, and concludes with suggestions for future research directions. Historical criminology is often associated with archival research, practical inquiry, a concern with temporality, and an interdisciplinary approach to scholarship. Archival research, as highlighted by Godfrey et al. (2017), provides a rich source of data for understanding the historical contexts of crime and justice, enabling researchers to uncover patterns and trends over time. Practical inquiry, on the other hand, emphasizes the application of historical knowledge to contemporary issues in criminology, as discussed by Lawrence (2019). The concern with temporality, a central theme in historical criminology, underscores the importance of historical time in shaping criminal behavior and justice responses, a point elaborated by Zedner (2018). Interdisciplinary scholarship, as advocated by Knepper and Scicluna (2020), encourages the integration of insights from history, sociology, law, and other disciplines to enrich the study of crime and justice. The significance of historical criminology to the wider field of criminology is multifaceted. It offers a deeper understanding of the historical roots of contemporary crime and justice issues, as noted by Garland (2018). By examining the evolution of criminal justice systems, historical criminology provides valuable insights into the persistence of certain practices and the emergence of new ones, as explored by Loader and Sparks (2017). Furthermore, historical criminology contributes to the development of theoretical frameworks that account for the temporal dimensions of crime, as argued by Karstedt (2019). The field also plays a crucial role in challenging presentist biases in criminological research, encouraging a more nuanced appreciation of the past, as highlighted by Wiener (2018). Looking to the future, historical criminology has the potential to make significant contributions to the development of criminology in several key areas. An inclusive global criminology, as proposed by Aas (2019), can benefit from historical perspectives that highlight the diverse experiences of crime and justice across different cultures and time periods. A criminology of events, as suggested by Young (2020), can draw on historical case studies to analyze the impact of specific events on crime and justice systems. Research on crime and justice futures, as envisioned by Loader and Sparks (2017), can utilize historical insights to anticipate and address emerging challenges in the field. In conclusion, historical criminology represents a vital and dynamic area of study that enriches our understanding of crime and justice through its focus on historical time and interdisciplinary scholarship. By continuing to explore its scope, significance, and future directions, historical criminology can make valuable contributions to the broader field of criminology and help shape its future development.
